data.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Taxonomic classification of viruses is a multi-class hierarchical classification problem, as taxonomic ranks (e.g., order, family and genus) of viruses are hierarchically structured and have multiple classes in each rank. Classification of biological sequences which are hierarchically structured with multiple classes is challenging. Here we developed a machine learning architecture, VirusTaxo, using a multi-class hierarchical classification by k-mer enrichment. VirusTaxo classifies DNA and RNA viruses to their taxonomic ranks using genome sequence. To assign taxonomic ranks, VirusTaxo extracts k-mers from genome sequence and creates bag-of-k-mers for each class in a rank. VirusTaxo uses a top-down hierarchical classification approach and accurately assigns the order, family and genus of a virus from the genome sequence. The average accuracies of VirusTaxo for DNA viruses are 99% (order), 98% (family) and 95% (genus) and for RNA viruses 97% (order), 96% (family) and 82% (genus). VirusTaxo can be used to detect taxonomy of novel viruses using full length genome or contig sequences.</jats:p><jats:sec><jats:title>Availability</jats:title><jats:p>Online version of VirusTaxo is available at<jats:ext-link xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="https://omics-lab.com/virustaxo/">https://omics-lab.com/virustaxo/</jats:ext-link>.</jats:p></jats:sec>
title: VirusTaxo: Taxonomic classification of virus genome using multi-class hierarchical classification by k-mer enrichment

reference.article-title: Genome Detective: an automated system for virus identification from high-throughput sequencing data

data.abstract: This chapter considers the clinical virology laboratory and reviews the use of virus genome detection for clinical diagnosis, which has increased dramatically. In general, virus genome detection is more rapid and sensitive than cell-culture and can be used before a detectable antibody response has developed. The chapter traces the discovery of potent antivirals for hepatitis C, hepatitis B, HIV, and influenza, wherein there is a huge demand for the diagnostic laboratory to monitor levels of virus in the appropriate clinical sample of the patient using rapid molecular tests. These tests can also give the first indication of drug-resistant virus mutants, which could compromise antiviral therapy. The chapter covers the collection and transport of clinical specimens to the laboratory, different rapid diagnostic methods, the isolation of viruses in cell cultures, and the detection of antiviral antibodies.
title: The clinical virology laboratory
